headline: Lawsuit seeks to block Georgia law that bans most abortions
author: KATE BRUMBACK
sentences:

If the law takes effect, some women who are able will travel out of state for the procedure, but other women will remain pregnant and give birth against their will or will seek to end their pregnancies outside of a clinical setting putting them at risk for harm, the lawsuit says.

Additionally, it declares an embryo or fetus a natural person? once cardiac activity can be detected, saying that is the point where the full value of a child begins.? That would make the fetus a dependent minor for tax purposes and trigger child support obligations.

ATLANTA (AP) - A federal lawsuit filed Friday in Atlanta is the latest effort by abortion providers and advocacy groups to challenge a wave of restrictive abortion laws passed in conservative-controlled state legislatures.

Lawyers with the American Civil Liberties Union, Planned Parenthood and the Center for Reproductive Rights filed the lawsuit challenging a new Georgia law that effectively bans abortions about six weeks into a pregnancy.

We will not accept any law that dehumanizes us in an attempt to assign humanity to cells that are growing inside of us,? said Kwajelyn Jackson, executive director of Feminist Womens Health Center, one of the plaintiffs.

A new Alabama law bans virtually all abortions, even in cases of rape or incest, and makes performing an abortion at any stage of pregnancy a felony punishable by 10 to 99 years or life in prison for the provider.

The law could also have a chilling effect on health care providers in the state because they might fear prosecution for any care they provide to pregnant patients that could harm a fetus, the lawsuit says.

Every day, our collective doors stay open so that you can access the quality, compassionate, non-judgmental health care that you deserve, and that includes access to safe and legal abortion,? Fox said.

Its one of a spate of laws passed recently by Republican-controlled legislatures in an attack on the U.S. Supreme Courts 1973 Roe v. Wade ruling that legalized abortion nationwide.
The lawsuit, filed on behalf of Georgia abortion providers and an advocacy group, asks a judge to prevent the law from taking effect and to declare it unconstitutional.
Women choose to have abortions for a variety of deeply personal reasons? that include family circumstances, medical concerns and financial situation, the lawsuit says.
The so-called heartbeat law bans abortion once a fetal heartbeat can be detected, which can occur as early as six weeks, before many women know theyre pregnant.
It also allows for abortions when the life of the woman is at risk or when a fetus is determined not to be viable because of a serious medical condition.
Its not unexpected that some group that wants abortion on demand is going to file a suit,? the bills main sponsor, Rep. Ed Setzler, said Friday.
The new definition of a fetus as a natural person? could have implications that are vague and potentially vast,? the lawsuit says.

The Georgia legislation makes exceptions in the case of rape and incest, if the woman files a police report first.
